title: "Fill markers" button doesn't work in "Writing a custom viewer for glue with Qt" tutorial
body:
**Describe the bug**
I'm following the "Writing a custom viewer for glue with Qt" tutorial. I have copied the `TutorialViewer` classes and `viewer_state.ui`. I load a csv file and I mostly obtain what is expected with one exception. The "Fill markers" toggle button does nothing. The `fill` property is never updated and the method `_on_fill_change`is never called.

If I add a callback to `self.checkbox`, than I can get the desired behavior, but `connect_checkable_button` is not working correctly.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior such as:
1. Copy the code in "Writing a custom viewer for glue with Qt" 
2. Load a CSV file
3. Drag to plot
4. Select "Tutorial Viewer"
5. Click on "Fill markers"

**Expected behavior**
Markers on the plot are filled.

**Details:**

- Operating System: Linux Fedora 37 
- Python version: Python 3.11.2, Python 3.10.10
- Glue version: 1.9.2.dev1+g4717aa72
- How you installed glue:  pip

title: Save legend state
body: While we were dealing with the issues with legends and matplotlib 3.7, I noticed that we don't save the legend state of the matplotlib viewers. This PR adds functionality to do that, which gives a small but nice UX improvement. This shouldn't have any effect on loading existing sessions, since then the relevant record won't have a `"legend"` key and the new code in `__setgluestate__` won't run.

body:
**Describe the bug**
The link editor find_object function is broken with 3+ datasets and at least some versions of PyQt5 and the latest dev version of glue. The problem is that 71ca079 changed to use event.position() [which seems correct for Qt6](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/67496362/qmouseevent-object-has-no-attribute-pos), but is not (generally?/always?) available for earlier versions.

**To Reproduce**
Add 3+ datasets and open the link editor with Qt5 installed. Attempting to click on a node in the link editor fails with 

> Traceback (most recent call last):

>     selected = self.find_object(event)

>     if obj.contains(event.position()):
> AttributeError: 'QMouseEvent' object has no attribute 'position'

title: Only recreate table model when Data layer changes
body:
This PR implements a change(/bugfix?) requested by @aagoodman. Currently, after a user makes a selection to create a new subset after having sorted the table, the sorting is undone once the subset is created. This leads to a not-great UX - if one is trying to create multiple selections based on a column's values, having to re-sort each time is annoying.

The reason for this is that the table model is recreated any time the layers change, which resets any sorting. This PR modifies the layer changed callback to only recreate the table model if the actual `Data` layer has changed - otherwise, we just call the model's `_update_visible`. This also necessitates making the masks in `_update_visible` aware of the current order.

title: Avoid interference of ROI patches with legend auto-placement
body:
## Description
Reported in #2368; as of matplotlib 3.7 legend auto-placement is affected by the position of ROIs, even if empty. Notably 4 tests in viewers/scatter failed as the default placement of a `MplPolygonalROI` pushed the legends out of their usual position.
As a workaround the default extent and position of the ROI is moved from `[0, 1], [0, 1]` to `[0.2, 0.3], [0.2, 0.3]` to keep out of the way of any of the 9 standard positions for the legend. Better fix would be to hold off syncing the patch until the ROI is made visible. Alternatively xfail for matplotlib >= 3.7.

title: Update polar log transform test values to correct matplotlib 3.7 representation
body:
One of the CI tests that has been failing lately is the test of `ProjectionMplTransform` in the case of a polar projection with a radial log axis. I believe the reason for the error is the fix in matplotlib PR 24825, which was added in 3.7.0. This PR aims to fix this test.

Plotting out the test points by hand, the new values in this PR are exactly what one would expect to see - at least to me, the old values don't make sense (hence the need for an upstream fix). Since this is a bug in old versions of matplotlib, I decided to mark the test as an xfail on an older MPL version. Along the way, I created a `make_xfailer` similar to `make_skipper`, and did a bit of refactoring since they have the same basic idea.

title: BUG: importing glue with setuptools>=67.3 raises a DeprecationWarning
body:
**Describe the bug**
`pkg_resources.get_distribution` was changed in `setuptools` 67.3, released last week, and now raises a deprecation warning on import.

`pkg_resources` as a whole is legacy and should be avoided, in particular because it creates a de facto runtime dependency on setuptools, which is currently undeclared.


**To Reproduce**
```shell
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
python -m pip install --upgrade setuptools
python -m pip install glue
python -Werror -c "import glue"
```

output
```
...
DeprecationWarning: Deprecated call to `pkg_resources.declare_namespace('mpl_toolkits')`.
Implementing implicit namespace packages (as specified in PEP 420) is preferred to `pkg_resources.declare_namespace`. See https://setuptools.pypa.io/en/latest/references/keywords.html#keyword-namespace-packages
```

**Expected behavior**
should return without error

**Details:**

- Operating System: all
- Python version (``python --version``): all
- Glue version (``glue --version``): 1.7.0
- How you installed glue: pip


I should be able to patch `pkg_resources` out completely.

title: Add pretransform for full-sphere selection
body: I realized that I missed one thing in #2348 with regards to selection. Any points whose latitudes were wrapped back into [-π,π] won't be selected when making a ROI selection because the scatter viewer's `apply_roi` doesn't know about that transformation. This PR adds a pretransform that lets it know about what happens with longitudes.

title: Represent `None` `component.units` as empty strings
body:
## Description

To fix issues as in spacetelescope/jdaviz#1909 where `f'{unit}'` returns unexpected results, this returns `self._units` of `None` as `''` for all `Component` subclasses. This is analogous to how these are already handled in `Coordinates`.
In case the internal value of `self._units == None` is still required somewhere, the second commit reverses the transformation on setting units, but it does not seem to be required for passing tests.

title: Fix export to Python script to correctly use `Coordinates` or `WCS` in `reference_data`
body:
## Description
This fixes an issue I found when trying to use the `Save Python script` function on a viewer using a dataset with a standard (Astropy) WCS, such as the example `w5.fits` data. The script thus created failed with an
> AttributeError: 'astropy.wcs.Wcsprm' object has no attribute 'pixel_n_dim'

on `ax.reset_wcs(slices=['x', 'y', 0], wcs=ref_data.coords.wcs)` as `ref_data.coords` itself is already the WCS.

The fix, to test for that case first in the exporter, seems quite straightforward.
I've parametrised some test to run on a dataset with WCS; could think about running this with all tests, or always adding a WCS in `self.data.coords`; however `test_subset_legend` still fails with this patch, as the version with WCS somehow is not including the subset label:
![expected](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/709020/195915629-2263f57c-333e-4eff-9d73-9effbcc74ad8.png)
![glue_plot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/709020/195915743-5615bc80-4579-4f4b-8e21-1f4126e2ae46.png)

Basically in the latter case the script is missing these lines:
```python
## Layer 2: mysubset

layer_data = data_collection[0].subsets[0]

# Define a function that will get a fixed resolution buffer of the mask
handle = mpatches.Patch(color='#e31a1c', alpha=0.5)
legend_handles.append(handle)
legend_labels.append(layer_data.label)
```
so this looks like another actual bug in the exporter (those lines were already missing before this change), as if in
https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/blob/aabb5ebb1b5227f973a99f9aa905d6bfe6988b0b/glue/viewers/common/viewer.py#L447

the subset layer is not `visible and enabled` when a WCS ist present (indeed `layer.enabled = False`), but I could not yet figure out why.

Actually comparing to the non-WCS plot it does not seem like the subset is really displayed in the WCS version:
![glue_plot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/709020/195943832-8ac30883-40f9-464f-b90f-3cdd11ee4ebe.png)

title: Don't change labels when using log x axis in histogram viewer
body: This PR, like #2323, addresses #2193. The original issue only mentioned the scatter viewer, which was taken care of in #2323, but the same logic applies to the x-axis label in the histogram viewer. This PR makes that change, as well as updates the histogram viewer's `test_axes_labels` test accordingly.

title: Fix issue where matplotlib viewers using ``y`` log axes were not initialized correctly.
body: This PR aims to fix #2194, which actually affects any of the matplotlib viewers that use log axes. The reason for the incorrect aspect described in the issue is that we currently only update the x log axes when setting up callbacks. This PR adds a call to `update_y_log` as well.

title: Don't change labels when using log scale axes
body: This PR addresses #2193. As pointed out there, "Log" shouldn't be prepended to the axis label when using log scale axes, since we aren't actually plotting the log of the component values. This also modifies the `test_axes_labels` test to account for this change.

title: Apply foreground color to minor ticks
body:
There is currently a bug where any minor ticks displayed will not match the user's global settings. (Note that this isn't an issue with the default settings, since the labels are black either way.) One prominent example is the scientific notation tick marks that are sometimes used when displaying an axis in log mode. See below for an example:

![log-label-colors](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14281631/171296270-548958ce-0e7b-4b72-8627-283437637cef.png)

This occurs because we only set major tick labels to match the given color in `set_foreground_color` (see the matplotlib documentation [here](https://matplotlib.org/3.1.1/api/_as_gen/matplotlib.axes.Axes.tick_params.html#matplotlib.axes.Axes.tick_params); the default value for `which` is `"major"`). This PR fixes the issue by setting `which="both"`).

title: Fix return shape of compute_statistic with view set or computed in chunks
body:
## Description
This is a follow-up/replacement for #2302, which identified a broadcast error when calling `compute_statistic` with a `RangeSubsetState` defined on `data.size > n_chunk_max`.
The underlying issue appears to be that a call with `subset_state` and `view` set like
`data.compute_statistic('mean', data.id['x'], axis=(1, 2), subset_state=subset_state, view=(slice(0, 6), ...))`
returns an array of the original axis-0 length with values past [:6] filled with NaN, while the same without a `subset_state` returns a length-6 array. This was probably introduced with the shape adjustments added as part of #2147.
Attempts to set the return shape in https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/blob/bc9382839d4a28d82c5a24aaedd50708bb198a00/glue/core/data.py#L1831
from `data.shape` or `mask.shape` instead did fix this issue, but broke the test cases in `test_compute_statistic_shape` again, so instead I am tracking here if a `view` was initially specified to directly return `result`.
I honestly do not completely understand how this works now for the combination of the efficient subset calculation _and_ `view` set, but the added tests are passing...

@rosteen could you test if this also fixes your case?

title: Redraw empty histogram layer
body:
This PR addresses an issue that was discussed at a glue meeting a little while ago (don't remember the exact date). The issue is that if a subset group is modified to make it empty, the corresponding histogram layer artist is not redrawn. See the video below.

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14281631/169853796-d7dd56b3-7d5b-4ed8-90a2-5931bc0a6e2e.mp4

The issue seems to be [here](https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/blob/main/glue/viewers/histogram/layer_artist.py#L82), where `_update_artists` return if the sum of the histogram is empty (that is, the layer has no content). To fix this, I've removed the `mpl_hist.sum() == 0` check. Allowing the possibility for empty layer opens the door for the `largest_y_max` and `smallest_y_min` values computed later in the method to be NaN or infinite (in particular, if all of the layers are empty). I couldn't think of a better default behavior than just punting on updating the bounds in this case, so I've added `numpy.isfinite` checks around both assignments to the relevant viewer state properties.

title: Force line collection to always respect colormap
body:
The scatter viewer currently has a bug (noticed by @victoriaono) where the line collection that connects points will only obey the selected colormap if that colormap was set before a line was first displayed on the viewer. Additionally, if a fixed color is set after the line displays, subsequent colormap usage will not be respected. See the video below for an example.

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14281631/169670639-f856a81a-ba8b-4c02-ad55-89c1e6b6b8aa.mp4

This PR creates consistent behavior by calling `set_color(None)` inside the line collection's `set_linearcolor` method. The reason for this has to do with how the behavior is implemented inside `matplotlib`. Whenever the colormap mode is Fixed, we call `set_linearcolor` with `color=self.state.color` [here](https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/blob/main/glue/viewers/scatter/layer_artist.py#L435). This call's the artist's [`set_color`](https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/blob/main/lib/matplotlib/collections.py#L715) method, which ultimately calls [`set_facecolor`](https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/blob/main/lib/matplotlib/collections.py#L742) and sets `_original_facecolor` to that color.

However, when  `cmap_mode` is set to `Linear`, we call `set_mpl_artist_cmap` [here](https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/blob/main/glue/viewers/scatter/layer_artist.py#L357) without a color argument, which doesn't doesn't call `set_color`, and so `_original_facecolor` remains as the solid color. The artist's `_edge_is_mapped` attribute is set to false [if `_original_edgecolor` has a color value](https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/blob/main/lib/matplotlib/collections.py#L857), which means that the edgecolors of the artist are [set to the original edgecolor, rather than the colormapped colors](https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/blob/main/lib/matplotlib/collections.py#L899). This is why things work if we set the colormap before the line first displays - we haven't made a call to the line collection's `set_color` method yet, so `_original_facecolor` is still `None`. By calling `set_color(None)`, we reset `_original_facecolor` to `None`, allowing the line collection edges to be colormapped.

title: TableViewer is buggy with incompatible subsets defined
body:
**Describe the bug**
The TableViewer throws and uncaught IncompatibleAttribute Error when an incompatible subset exists in the data collection and the underlying data set for the TableViewer is toggled to be invisible, as one might do when attempting to view another **valid** subset. 

**To Reproduce**
1. Created two unlinked datasets: d1 and d2
2. Define a subset on d2
3. Create a table viewer for d1
4. Toggle the visibility of d1 in the table viewer to generate the uncaught Error and cause the TableViewer to glitch.

**Expected behavior**
No error should be thrown.

**Details:**

- MacOS 12.3
- Python 3.8.13
- Glue version 1.2.5.dev58+ge8f03f18 (current dev)

**Additional context**
Pull request to fix is forthcoming...

title: BUG: deprecation warning handling in 1.2.4 is problematic
body:
**Describe the bug**
In testing yt, we treat warnings as errors within pytest jobs.

however with the latest glue-core release we're getting a warning, outside of our control:
```
DeprecationWarning: the load_module() method is deprecated and slated for removal in Python 3.12; use exec_module() instead
```
So the most natural workaround on yt's side would be to ignore specifically this warning, but for some reason I didn't manage to do that (see https://github.com/yt-project/yt/pull/3759)

I think this comes from the fact that glue-core is explicitly using `raise` in he following line, even if the parent exception is really a warning, preventing pytest to effectively ignore it
https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/blob/094e5ae8aff72434c08f0c307f1c7af4af9bea03/glue/config.py#L1009


**To Reproduce**

```toml
#pyproject.toml
filterwarnings = ["error"]
```

```python
# test.py
import glue
```

```
python3.10 -m pytest test.py
```

**Expected behavior**
Ideally, this warning shouldn't be raised at all (follow the recommendation it contains)

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Details:**

- Operating System: irrelevant
- Python version (``python --version``): 3.10 (this warning didn't exists on previous versions)
- Glue version (``glue --version``): 1.2.4
- How you installed glue: pip

**Additional context**

title: Installation fails on Python 3.10 + MacOS
body:
**Describe the bug**

I'm surprised that I didn't find any similar issue in the tracker, apologies if I just didn't look close enough

Right now glueviz fails to build on my machine with MacOS 12.0.1 (Monterey) and Python 3.10.0
```
pip install glueviz
```

As far as I understand, the real problem is with bottleneck (a build time dependency to glue) not being maintained, with many build-related issues in their tracker
https://github.com/pydata/bottleneck/issues

I wonder if there's anything that can be done on glueviz' side to mitigate this problem, like making bottleneck an optional dependency (maybe just for Python 3.10 and above) ? 


**Details:**

- Operating System: MacOS 12.0.1
- Python version (``python --version``): Python 3.10.0
- Glue version (``glue --version``): None
- How you installed glue: couldn't

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

title: Fixes to profile viewer
body:
This fixes three issues with the profile viewer:

* The home button now correctly resets the y limits
* The visibility checkbox for profile viewer layers now works correctly
* The limits of the profile viewer are now no longer reset every time e.g. a subset is updated or a dataset is added - instead they are reset only when requested by the user or if the reference data changes (as for the image viewer)

body:
Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/2148

@keflavich - can you confirm this works for you?

body:
I've created some subsets on a CASA-produced "alpha" map.  I tried making a histogram, and got the message that I can't visualize the subset because it's made from something undefined for the data set.


This screenshot shows the error:

title: Legend and background color
body:
Viewers can have a custom background/foreground color (which can be changed in the preferences), for example white on black instead of black on white. We might want to consider making the legend follow this so that the background and text color match the rest of the figure:

![Screenshot from 2020-05-20 15-01-34](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/314716/82455423-d6f94680-9aaa-11ea-8c53-66f3c908a278.png)

cc @specmicp

title: Fix a bug where x_att and y_att could end up being out of sync in image viewer
body: This caused issues in glue-jupyter because of the way the callbacks are set up there for the image viewer (the image data is retrieved sooner after a change in reference data)

title: Fixed missing .units on CoordinateComponent
body: This was an oversight, we should pull in the units from the WCS

title: Fix table viewer performance
body: This fixes a bug that caused an infinite loop in the table viewer and caused glue to hang if too many incompatible subsets were in a table viewer

title: Fix State.update_from_dict when nested states are present
body: With this it is now possible to update states that have callback lists containing states

title: Fixed a bug that caused an error when an invalid data was added to the table viewer
body:
and the table viewer was then automatically closed. The error was:

```
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '_data'
```

title: Fixed the dropdowns for vector and error markers to not include datetime components
body: Since datetime components represent absolute times, not deltas

title: Fixed a bug that caused issues when saving and re-loading sessions with Excel data
body: String columns from Excel files were incorrectly read in as object arrays.

title: Fixed a bug with re-loading sessions that had LinkCollections
body: This should fix issues with opening the link editor after re-loading a session with complex links

title: Minor fixes to layer artists
body: This makes a few small tweaks to fix issues in glue-jupyter related to removing data from layers

title: Fix issue where profile of subset was not correctly hidden if the subset was emptied
body: This was first spotted in glue-jupyter (https://github.com/glue-viz/glue-jupyter/issues/160) but the issue exists in glue-core too.

title: Compatibility with Matplotlib 3.1.3
body:
(Continuation of the discussion in https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/pull/2090, because it is unrelated)

Tests in glue/viewers/image/qt/tests/test_data_viewer.py are failing:

- test_slice_change_single_draw
- test_update_subset_ignored_if_not_present

(example of failed tests: https://dev.azure.com/glue-viz/glue/_build/results?buildId=487&view=logs&jobId=e31e1c80-7337-58fc-f10c-7ed77e80e102&j=e31e1c80-7337-58fc-f10c-7ed77e80e102&t=df35b83d-b4d5-50fc-c648-b1233c5c329f )

Fails only occur with Matplotlib 3.1.3 but not with Matplotlib 3.1.2

with matplotlib 3.1.3: this version of the test is not working:

```python
    def test_update_subset_ignored_if_not_present(self):
        # This can be quite a difficult test to pass because it makes sure that
        # there are absolutely no references to the layer state left over once
        # a subset is removed - when originally written this identified quite
        # a few places where references were being accidentally kept, and
        # resulted in weakref being needed in a number of places. But ultimately
        # this test should pass! No cheating :)
        self.init_draw_count()
        self.data_collection.append(self.data)
        self.viewer.add_data(self.data)
        sub = self.data.new_subset()
        #print(self.draw_count)
        self.viewer.remove_subset(sub)
        ct0 = self.draw_count
        assert self.draw_count == ct0
```

However, this version is passing (only difference is the print(self.draw_count):
```python
    def test_update_subset_ignored_if_not_present(self):
        # This can be quite a difficult test to pass because it makes sure that
        # there are absolutely no references to the layer state left over once
        # a subset is removed - when originally written this identified quite
        # a few places where references were being accidentally kept, and
        # resulted in weakref being needed in a number of places. But ultimately
        # this test should pass! No cheating :)
        self.init_draw_count()
        self.data_collection.append(self.data)
        self.viewer.add_data(self.data)
        sub = self.data.new_subset()
        print(self.draw_count)
        self.viewer.remove_subset(sub)
        ct0 = self.draw_count
        assert self.draw_count == ct0
```

it seems that it is unrelated to what the test is really testing, and more due to a delayed drawing/processing of the events...

This is the changelog of matplotlib 3.1.3: https://matplotlib.org/3.1.3/users/whats_new.html

These are the commits between 3.1.2 and 3.1.3: https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/compare/v3.1.2...v3.1.3

One of the maybe relevant commit changing the behavior of draw_idle is : https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/commit/12004eda6ab4192511f5f6727980e106038fdde5

I do not understand in details the internal of matplotlib, so I'm not sure how to continue this investigation, but I hope this information helps.

title: Fix importer for directories - now a seperate import menu item
body: @keflavich - this should fix the issues you were seeing under Linux

title: Fixed bugs related to profile viewer and loading session files
body:
This fixes several bugs:

* Fixed a bug with the profile viewer which caused layers to not update correctly when changing the reference data
* Fixed issue with reloading session with profile viewer that has a non-default reference data
* Improve how we deal with backward-compatibility related to change in Data.coords to ``None``

title: Make sure autolinker is called when using qglue
body: I need to check if there's any other places this is missing and should probably also add a button to do this manually if needed.

title: Fix several bugs with scatter viewer
body: Fixes #2040 and a couple of other bugs

title: Issue when plotting using line
Fix initialization of table viewer with subset instead of dataset
Fixes to preferences dialog
body: This fixes a couple of issues - first the preferences dialog would crash if no autolinkers were present, which could happen if astropy <3.1 was installed. Second, the preferences dialog sometimes got sent behind the main application window when editing the color, so I've made it modal.

title: Fix bug in autoconnect_callbacks_to_qt
body: The bug caused the x/y/z_stretch sliders in the 3D viewers to not work correctly because they were linked to the same state callback property as the text box with the slider value.

title: Fixes following 0.15.0 release
body:
This fixes a few things:

* It makes glue give a more explicit error message if Astropy is not recent enough for auto-linking
* It fixes the tox configuration to properly test the installed version
* It fixes the version number in ``__version__``

title: Fix dragging of existing ROIs
body:
This is leftover from the recent refactoring of the ROI code (https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/pull/1983)

Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/2025

title: Fix path to data bundle when exporting Python script
body: Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1922

title: No longer offer to merge datasets by default
body:
Now that e.g. the image and 3D volume rendering viewers can show linked datasets, merging is becoming les and less useful, except maybe for making scatter plots of one dataset against another pixel-aligned dataset. So this PR makes it so that we no longer offer to merge data by default, which often confused users. Instead, users should manually select and merge data.

* [x] What's new entry
* [x] Add back some degree of auto-merging for e.g. HDF5 files with one column per dataset
* [x] Check documentation to see if anything needs to be updated

This also fixes a number of test failures I ran into while working on this.

Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1950
Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/2017
Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1978

title: Viewer options are broken in development build
body:
Drop-downs for the 3D scatter plot viewer and WWT viewer do not populate with the fields of the data set, and the only option that works for these viewer is changing the marker color via the color picker.

Based on local testing, it looks like this issue was introduced in pull request #1998.

title: Fix bug with categorical histograms
body: Fixed bug that caused labels on the x-axis of the histogram viewer to be incorrectly set to numbers instead of strings when showing a histogram of a string variable and saving/reloading session

body: Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1854

body: after the link dialog was closed.

title: Error bars with sudden color scale issue
body:
Hi!

I'm an astronomy student working on some datafile. The issue I'm having here is that when plotting error bars in a 2d scatter plot, the error bars get a specific color when you assigned a color scheme to one of the parameters of the 2d scatter plot. It _seems_ unrelated to the value of the datapoint, but I can't seem to find a pattern or reason for Glue doing so.

Attached are picture 1, without error bars, with a color scaling to the x-axis, as is easily seen.
Picture 2 then shows the same plot with error bars, with colors appearing quite randomly, but it is always the same (hence my efforts to find a pattern). 

There is no option in Glue for these colors in error bars as far as I can see. 
Does someone know what is going on here?

Cheers!

Rutger

![gh1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45002288/53883495-6edf5180-4019-11e9-944c-592dad6a9f2f.png)

![gh2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45002288/53883506-7272d880-4019-11e9-9780-789979f08ee3.png)

body: Partial fix for #1926

This is a bit of a hacky solution, but I couldn't find a cleaner way to do it.

title: Fixed a bug that occurred when pandas DataFrame included a datetime column
body: Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1912

title: Any error in python console kills execution
body:
If I force an error in the python console, it enters a state where it continues to run but will no longer execute anything. The only way to reset is to kill Glue - if I close and reopen the terminal, still the same.
```
In [1]: dc
Out[1]: 
DataCollection (0 data sets)
	

In [2]: xxx
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
NameError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-38170c08cb45> in <module>
----> 1 xxx

NameError: name 'xxx' is not defined

In [3]: dc
ERROR: execution aborted
```

title: date data cannot be displayed by scatter
body:
New to Glue here. If I create an excel sheet with two numeric columns and one date column, I can import everything, and the dtype of the date column is properly datetime64. When I drag the data into the viewer, I can see it in a table view. When I request a scatter view, though, to see the numbers over time, I get a popup with this message:
```
Failed to add data
Unknown data kind
```
The "Show Details..." is below. If I change the format of the date cells in the excel file to "number" it imports and displays properly as numbers.

From previous issues, it seems like this used to work. Even if the scatter viewer can't manage dates, there's no way to look at the other two columns - maybe that's a different issue.

title: Fix issue with reading in VO Tables
body:
Due to a change in either Numpy or Astropy (haven't had a chance to investigate which), reading of VO Tables with non-float columns was broken. This PR fixes this.

Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1910

title: Fix get_mask when key joins are present
body:
This fixes an issue that occurred when getting masks with ``Data.get_mask`` - this would ignore any key joins set up previously. I've now moved the key join code so that it gets called in ``Data.get_mask`` now instead of ``Subset.to_mask``

Fixes #1899

title: Dendrogram subset color is incorrect
body: It looks like dendrogram subsets are the wrong color when using the dragging selection mode (basically the lines cycle through all the different matplotlib colors). This is a regression and should be fixed in a quick 0.14.1 release.

title: Data.get_mask does not take into account key joins
body: The 3D viewers rely on the new ``Data.get_mask`` API, but currently this doesn't take into account key joins. This has caused a regression where selections between dendrograms and 3D viewers no longer propagate either way, so I need to fix this urgently and put out a 0.14.1 bugfix release.

title: Make sure qglue works correctly with BaseData subclasses
body: @maartenbreddels - this should fix the issue you were seeing in glue-jupyter

title: Fixed a bug due to Numpy not being imported under certain circumstances
body: This happened if Numpy was imported (as np) in ``config.py`` (which is a completely valid thing to do)

title: Fix Plot.ly exporter
body: This makes the plot.ly exporter functional again, and removes the option to publish to the glue account (since the maximum number of plots is easily reached)

title: Fix missing svg icons in installed package
body: Previously the .svg icons were not actually installed

title: Require Astropy >=2
body: Currently we require Astropy >=1.3 but I think some of the functionality actually requires 2+

title: Fix compatibility with Matplotlib 3.0
body: Modest image was accessing private attributes...

title: Glue 0.13.3 crash with 2D Scatter on Windows
body:
hello, I'm a new glue user and really enjoying Glue!

I have been able to narrow a crash (see exception below) with Glue 0.13.3 on Windows down to using "2D scatter" on a 2 col dataframe, where one field is numeric and the other categorical (strings), with ~100K rows.
```
Unhandled exception at 0x00007FFEE4BF3022 (_histogram_core.cp36-win_amd64.pyd) in python.exe:
0xC0000005: Access violation reading location 0x000001448CD0C030.
```

Here's the code to reproduce a crash on average every other time I run it:

```python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from glue.qglue import parse_data
from glue.core import DataCollection
from glue.app.qt.application import GlueApplication
from glue.viewers.scatter.qt import ScatterViewer

end = 111_000
x_label = 'abcde'
y_label = 'ghi_jklmn'
x = list(sorted(np.random.randint(7000, 33600, end)))
y = (pd.Series(np.random.randint(0, 4, end), dtype=str) + '_' +
     pd.Series(np.random.randint(0, 2, end), dtype=str))
df = pd.DataFrame({x_label: x, y_label: y})

d = parse_data(df, 'myData')[0]
dc = DataCollection([d])
ga = GlueApplication(dc)
scatter = ga.new_data_viewer(ScatterViewer)
scatter.add_data(d)
ga.start()

```

The call stack at time of exception is below, but not sure how to debug from that alone.

title: Fix bug that caused exception if self.log was not defined in state
Don't require override_mode to be passed to ApplySubsetState command
body: This fixes compatibility with the 3D viewers (and potentially other users of the ``ApplySubsetState`` command.

title: Fix a bug that caused custom data importers to not work correctly
body: Previously selecting a custom importer would just result in the data wizard being opened.

title: Fix default dataset in arithmetic and rename/reorder dialogs
body:
Make it so that when control-clicking on datasets to open the dialogs to create arithmetic attributes or rename/reorder components, the selected dataset is shown

Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1725

title: Fix bug that caused ROIs to persist after selection
body: Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1775

title: Preserve dtype when writing to FITS and HDF5
body: Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1751

title: Fixes related to Export Data dialog
body: This fixes issues when opening the 'Export Data' dialog when no data is present, and also when it is opened and the data collection is subsequently changed (which caused Qt errors due to circular references)

title: Fix bug with subset dragging
body: Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1780

title: Avoid repeated coordinate components in merged datasets
body: Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1782

title: Fix slicing of categorical_ndarray
body:
Prior to this fix, codes were re-computed after slicing/masking, which meant that subsets didn't have the correct codes.

Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1790

title: Issue with selection of categorical components
body: The codes appear to be recomputed for the subset, but we should re-use the categories from the main dataset. Maybe the issue is that slicing a ``categorical_ndarray`` causes the codes to be recomputed, in which case we should look into fixing that.

title: When merging datasets, too many coordinate components are present
body: In an example Alyssa ran today, the merged data had 3 times each coordinate component.

title: Moving a subset should never result in a new subset being created
body: When using the selection dragging, the selection mode should be ignored and it should always be assumed to be 'replace'.

title: Issue when updating a subset that isn't in a scatter plot
body: I had an issue when trying to update Subset 3 where Subset 3 is not one of the subsets shown in the scatter plot. Basically the selection tool doesn't go away (might require a redraw).

title: Miscellaneous fixes
body:
This makes the following fixes:

* Improves the code to disable selection tools after use
* Avoid errors in the profile and histogram layer artists if the hub is not yet defined
* Expanded the docstring for format_minimal to specify return values
* Avoid broadcasting messages from SubsetGroup if label doesn't actually change
* Fix the visibility of profiles
* Fixes errors that could happen due to race conditions in the profile and histogram viewers

title: Another fix related to threading
body: This avoids a race condition in postthread

title: IPython ``user_ns`` keeps track of previous cell outputs
body: When using the built-in IPython console, IPython keeps track of any previously output variable. This is a problem if accessing viewers programmatically via IPython since this prevents viewers from being properly garbage collected.

title: Make sure we clean up things in viewers when closing viewers via the GUI
body: This bypasses the ``close`` method so we need to do this in the ``closeEvent`` instead.

title: Avoid circular references when closing viewer
body: This gets rid of some residual circular references that persisted after closing a viewer

title: Fix display of 'Computing...' message
Fix profile computation for subsets
body: There was a subtle bug that affected profile viewers - if a thread was stopped and restarted before it had actually stopped, the thread wasn't actually restarted and the subset shown didn't always reflect the latest actual subset. The profile thread for each layer now runs more like a daemon in that it runs continuously and listens for messages asking it to compute the profile. This also fixes other bugs that popped up while investigating this.

title: Preserve floating-point type when exporting data
body: When exporting 32-bit data/masked data, we should preserve the original data type

title: Fix compute_statistic and add tests
body: This is a work in progress - I still need to add the tests!

title: Fix thread issue
body:
This ensures we don't destroy a thread without waiting for it to be interrupted properly. Prior to this this could result in segmentation faults.

Also added the missing changelog entry for #1737

title: Fix parsing of AVM meta-data
body: Also moved the image parsing tests into their own files

title: Rename/reorder component dialog should select correct dataset
body: When opening the component manager from the contextual menu for a given dataset, the component manager should show the correct dataset by default.

title: Miscellaneous fixes
body:
Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1709
Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1710
Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1711

body: This bug caused meta derived from FITS headers to not be serializable

title: Make sure header values are converted to strings in meta
body: Otherwise saving the session fails

title: Miscellaneous fixes
body: Various bug fixes - mostly affecting the developer version (not released versions)

title: Fix bug related to indexing order
body: Fixing the issue reduced the performance of slicing of reprojected cubes, which was previously over-simplified. To speed this up, I've adding caching of the pixel coordinate transformations. I've also fixed an unrelated bug in the profile viewer.

title: Miscellaneous fixes
body:
This includes the following fixes:

* Fixes the metadata dialog for non-FITS data
* Fixes a bug when converting from world to pixel coordinates which caused issues when using two cubes with different projections in the same image viewer
* Fixes a bug that occurred when in some reprojection cases an empty list/array of coordinates was passed to the world <-> pixel functions
* Fixes a bug that caused the image viewer slices to not be reset correctly when changing reference data
* Improves the single pixel selection mode to add crosshairs

title: Velocity shown in pixel coordinates in PV Slice View
body:
In the latest developer version, when a cut is made in p-v space, the velocity axis (and maybe also the position along cut axis) has units of pixels instead of units of meters per second. 


![pv_slice](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/18339657/37302181-2c5a237c-2601-11e8-9eb6-c37d4f5dee96.png)

You'll see that the velocity axis has height 630 which is the length in pixels of the velocity axis of the cube.

title: Log axis labels in 1D histograms
body:
The .glu file that can reproduce the behavior below is at https://www.dropbox.com/sh/0p1lwz6npax5gwa/AAC2j4Va98Vp7So6DtKtn6hma?dl=0.

What happens?  When you make a histogram & ask for (both, or one) log axes, the tick labeling is not right, as shown below.
![preglufilemessedupx](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2521688/37258577-626aa86c-2550-11e8-95f8-65c9127bcc00.jpg)

Miraculously, if you save the file as a .glu session, the situation improves somewhat.  The same plot shown above opens with the x-axis labels fixed, but the y-axis labels no longer "log" and in fact just oddly wrong?
![onopeningglufile](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2521688/37258576-625808ba-2550-11e8-9e55-4b35a50b4cef.jpg)

But, then, if you click log on and off a few times, you can get the axes to look right, as below.
![bothlogaxesright_afterclicklogonlogofflogon](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2521688/37258574-6217996a-2550-11e8-8476-ed792045cf1a.jpg)

Oddly, at some point of all the on/off clicking, they can also look like this.
![yaxiswrong_fromglufile](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2521688/37258575-62227e8e-2550-11e8-9d7b-1249e224e519.jpg)

title: Slow propagation of subsets
body:
Here is a use case that is very slow when trying to propagate subsets:

* Link a 2D galactic image with a 3D equatorial cube
* Make a 3D view of the cube (to force the whole subset to be computed)
* Select a region in the 2D image

Slowness ensues because we don't use the 'fast' shortcut for projecting the selection along the spectral dimension of the cube. We can fix this by checking for dimensions that are not related to any of the selection dimensions via any link.

title: glue.qglue() blocks on the second call
body:
In a `jupyter console`, if `glue.qglue(a=[1])` is called twice, it will block on the second call.

### Reproduce
```
# start a console in bash
$ jupyter console
Jupyter console 5.1.0 ...
Python 3.6.2 ...
IPython 5.3.0 ...

In [1]: %gui qt5

In [2]: import glue
Qt WebEngine seems to be initialized from a plugin. Please set Qt::AA_ShareOpenGLContexts using QCoreApplication::setAttribute before constructing QGuiApplication.

# start a qglue(), this returns immediately
In [3]: app = glue.qglue(a=[1])
QCoreApplication::exec: The event loop is already running

# =====> this step reproduces the bug:
# close the GUI created by In [3], (you have to close it to reproduce the bug),
# start another one, this one blocks, it returns when the GUI is closed
# Expect: returns immediately, like the one created by In [3]
In [4]: app = glue.qglue(a=[1])
```

### Version:
```
$ pip show glueviz
Name: glueviz
Version: 0.11.1
```

title: Selecting "Swap Axes" on a 2D scatter plot (log scales) changes the plot limits for the Y axis
body:
A screen grab showing the problem is available in the gist https://gist.github.com/DougBurke/114ae9139263b2d18ec6bc57df3835cf - both plots were created in the same way, but then for the second plot I hit "Swap Axes".

I have a 2D scatter plot, log scale selected for both axes, and the limits (as listed by glue) are

x: 0.86... to 133.192  (too lazy to copy all the decimal places on the minimum)
y: 6.8403 to 150103

If I select "Swap Axes" then the limits are now

x: 6.8403 to 150103
y: 0.00139918 to 133.192

and so the plot wastes a lot of space. I expected the Y axis to be 0.86... to 133.192. If I now select "Swap Axes" then the plot goes back to its original limits.

I suspect it's because the X column (i.e. the one that covers 0.8 to 131) has one row with a np.inf value in it. And in fact, if I create a new scatter plot with the choice of columns swapped then I see the reverse behavior, in that the original version has the Y axis being 0.0014 to 133 and after swapping the X axis is now 0.9 to 133.

A data file for this problem can be found in https://gist.github.com/DougBurke/114ae9139263b2d18ec6bc57df3835cf - the columns are significance and likelihood in the first block (`MST_SP`) of `gluetest.fits. I originally created a test file with just these two columns but then this doesn't exhibit the problem, so I kept in two extra columns at the start, assuming that it is some subtle difference in initialization/set up that causes this problem.

title: Facet subset bug: bin number not a multiple of steps will mess up the segementation
body:
I create faceted subsets with steps=5, low=1, high=6, parameter=RV, the correct result is shown with the default bin=15 as:

Should we keep bin number only be multiple to the steps? Thanks! @astrofrog

title: Fix crashes in image viewer when removing subsets

The Home button no longer functions (I can't go wide screen anymore) but no error is produced in the error console.*

title: Fix clearing of layers in Matplotlib viewers
body: Make it so LayerArist.clear doesn't actually remove the Matplotlib artists but just hides them until the layer is next enabled (this sets set_visible(False) on the artist directly, bypassing LayerState.visible which can remain True/False)

title: Fix ComponentLink.compute if view causes a scalar to be returned
body: This was a bug introduced when changing Component.numeric to check a single value instead of all values.

title: Fix residual subset in image after layer artist is removed
body: Make sure the imshow artist for image subsets is added to mpl_artists so as to get removed when the layer artist is cleared

title: loading of unstructured numpy arrays
body:
Hi,

I was just experimenting with glueviz and dumped some of my data into a .npy file only to find that glueviz had trouble loading it! When loading an numpy array saved to a .npy file I got the following traceback from loading the data in glueviz
```
Error message: 'NoneType' object is not iterable

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "D:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\glue\dialogs\data_wizard\qt\data_wizard_dialog.py", line 38, in data_wizard
    result = gdd.load_data()
  File "D:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\glue\dialogs\data_wizard\qt\data_wizard_dialog.py", line 109, in load_data
    d = load_data(path, factory=fac.function)
  File "D:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\glue\core\data_factories\helpers.py", line 237, in load_data
    d = as_list(factory(path, **kwargs))
  File "D:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\glue\core\data_factories\helpers.py", line 330, in auto_data
    return fac(filename, *args, **kwargs)
  File "D:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\glue\core\data_factories\npy.py", line 39, in npy_reader
    for name in npy_data.dtype.names:
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable
```


I checked [glue/glue/core/data_factories/npy.py](https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/blob/master/glue/core/data_factories/npy.py) and saw the ValueError that mentions currently only structured numpy arrays are supported
 
``` python
if not hasattr(npy_data.dtype, 'names'):
        raise ValueError("Numpy save file loading currently only supports structured"
                         " arrays, e.g., with specified names.")
```

I didn't realize you could have unstructured or structured arrays in numpy so I looked into it and found a pretty basic workaround in my case that took my input of a 230x230x512 array of float32 values and copied it in a structured way
```python
import numpy as np
from np.random import rand
a = rand(230, 230, 512) # unstructured dummy data
b = np.array(a, dtype='float32, float32, float32') # structured copy of a
np.save('filesave1.npy', a)
np.save('filesave2.npy', b) # loadable by glueviz
```
However, I found all this not due to the ValueError I quoted above but because an unstructured multidimensional numpy array still has a names attribute, it is just Nonetype, which cannot be iterated on as it does further down in the loader function.
```python
for name in npy_data.dtype.names:
        comp = Component.autotyped(npy_data[name])
        d.add_component(comp, label=name)
```

### suggestion?

Since an unstructured array still has a nonempty name (`a.dtype.name` in my example above returns `'float32'`) attribute, if input file is unstructured and thus names is Nonetype, you could map the dtype of name and structure the dimensions of your unstructure input array.

At the very least, the if statement should be changed to catch the Nonetype of the names attribute so you get the actual ValueError exception raised.

title: Duplicate links when reading in session file
body: If I set up simple identity links, then save and reload the session file, there are additional links added: **Before:** **After saving and reloading:** One thing that I realized when looking at session files is that when loading a session file, we loop through the links property in the save data collection and then add these, but links may also be added because of the derived components being loaded on the data objects.

title: Fix how we deal with component IDs for linked components
body:
Previously, when linking two components, we added the component ID of the linked component in each dataset to the other dataset, and set .hidden to True. However since the component ID was shared, this also hid the component ID in the original data. Instead, we now don't hide the component IDs, but instead treat component IDs where .parent is not the dataset being looked at to be effectively hidden.

Fixes https://github.com/glue-viz/glue/issues/1257

title: Fix font sizes across platforms
body:
On Linux and Windows, font sizes were sometimes mismatched - this is because the default system font size changes depending on the platform/screen size/resolution. The best solution is therefore to not hard-code any font sizes in the ui files but instead to set font sizes in relative terms in the actual Python code.

Before this can be merged, I need to fix the font size for the dialogs (where this has been removed here) and then also add a command to Travis to make sure there are no font sizes hard-coded in ui files.

title: Issue with selecting from images that are linked via world coordinates
body:
Here's a use case that often causes confusion:
- Take two FITS images with different WCS but both with RA/Dec
- Load them into two separate image viewers. Because we use WCSAxes, the axes show Ra/Dec but we are really plotting the images in pixel space
- Link the RA and Dec components
- Make a selection in one image viewer.

The selection does not propagate to the other viewer. This is because the selection is defined in pixel space, not in RA/Dec space.

I thought we used to automatically link the world coordinates with the pixel coordinates, so that the selection _should_ have been translated into an RA/Dec selection, but I may be mis-remembering.

@ChrisBeaumont - did this ever work?

title: Issue with linking derived components
body:
Linking derived components via the GUI currently does not work. The following example replicates what happens when using the GUI:

``` python
from glue.core.component_link import ComponentLink
from glue.core import Data, DataCollection
from glue.core.component_id import ComponentID
from glue.core.parse import ParsedCommand, ParsedComponentLink

data1 = Data(x=[1,2,3,4,5], y=[1,2,3,4,5], label='data1')
data2 = Data(a=[1,2,3,4,5], b=[1,2,3,4,5], label='data2')

dc = DataCollection([data1, data2])

labels = {'data2:a': data2.id['a'], 'data2:b': data2.id['b']}
pc = ParsedCommand("{data2:a} - {data2:b}", labels)
new_id = ComponentID('color')
link2 = ParsedComponentLink(new_id, pc)
data2.add_component_link(link2)

link4 = ComponentLink([data1.id['x']], data2.id['a'])

dc.add_link(link4)

print(data2['color'])
```

The error is:

``` python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "simple.py", line 21, in <module>
    print(data2['color'])
  File "/Users/tom/Dropbox/Code/development/glue-viz/glue/glue/core/data.py", line 628, in __getitem__
    result = comp.data
  File "/Users/tom/Dropbox/Code/development/glue-viz/glue/glue/core/component.py", line 240, in data
    return self._link.compute(self._data)
  File "/Users/tom/Dropbox/Code/development/glue-viz/glue/glue/core/parse.py", line 180, in compute
    return self._parsed.evaluate(data, view)
  File "/Users/tom/Dropbox/Code/development/glue-viz/glue/glue/core/parse.py", line 147, in evaluate
    return eval(cmd, vars(env), locals())  # careful!
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/tom/Dropbox/Code/development/glue-viz/glue/glue/core/data.py", line 619, in __getitem__
    raise IncompatibleAttribute(key)
glue.core.exceptions.IncompatibleAttribute: a
```

What's happening here is that the derived component is permanently referred to by the string `"{data2:a} - {data2:b}"`. Furthermore, when doing the linking of the single component with `ComponentLink([data1.id['x']], data2.id['a'])`, `a` is replaced by `x` in `data2`, so the parsed command no longer works.

It's not clear what the best way to deal with this would be, but another question that comes up here is whether we should actually be replacing component IDs upon linking at all (I find this to be counter-intuitive and it causes issues as shown here)

@ChrisBeaumont - do you have any thoughts here?

title: Minor visual misfeatures
body:
When viewing a FITS image using `vispy` as a backend (I assume; it's whatever glue defaulted to) I find a few minor glitches:
- When I select stretch and functional transform in the contrast menu the menu does not show my settings if I go back. It would be nice to be able to see the current settings, since I may not remember and it can inform my next attempt to improve the display.
- When I click on the contrast tool it highlights without showing me the menu. This appears to be intentional (going into a mode where I can manually drag to change contrast), but is rather surprising. Please consider showing a menu where one option is drag-to-change and one is to reset to the default (as if the user never dragged). Or add a tool -- one toggles, one has a menu?

title: Region of interest bug not displaying in some image (and very slow?)
body:
This bug was discovered during the Glue tutorial at Python in Astronomy 2016. I have shared the files with @astrofrog privately. Here is the workflow:
1. Use Image Viewer to display `s1_mips_v0.30_sci.fits` (Viewer 1).
2. Use another Image Viewer to display `s12_ch1_v0.30_sci.fits` (Viewer 2).
3. Open `s12_ch1_v0.30_sci.fits` again in Viewer 1 (so this image is now on both viewers).
4. Use circular region of interest tool to select a star.

You will notice that:
1. It is very slow? It was on my Windows 7 laptop.
2. The region appears on both viewers initially. But when you switch displayed image on Viewer 1 from `s1_mips...` to `s12_ch1...`, the region disappears on Viewer 1.

title: PyQtGraph widgets appear blurred when inside glue
body:
We discussed this with @nmearl and found that we could avoid this by explicitly setting the widget to use OpenGL, but this is likely only a workaround. The minimal example from @nmearl is:

``` python
from PySide import QtGui
import numpy as np
import pyqtgraph as pg

app = QtGui.QApplication([])

win = QtGui.QMainWindow()
win.resize(800, 800)
imv = pg.ImageView()
win.setCentralWidget(imv)
win.show()

data = np.random.sample(size=(1000, 1000)) * 1e10
imv.setImage(data)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    import sys
    if (sys.flags.interactive != 1) or not hasattr(QtCore, 'PYQT_VERSION'):
        QtGui.QApplication.instance().exec_()
```

and the workaround was to use

``` python
pg.setConfigOption("useOpenGL", True)
```

title: XLS / XLSX loader issue. 'Sheet1'
body:
Hi there,

If you try to import an XLSX spreadsheet, and it doesn't have a worksheet called "Sheet1", GlueViz deals a "Could not lead data (wrong load method?)" "File load method: Excel" error.
1. The loader should load the first sheet in the worksheet, regardless of its name. xlrd has methods to do this, e.g.
   xl_workbook = xlrd.open_workbook(filename)
   xl_sheet = xl_workbook.sheet_by_index(0)
2. While on this, other sheets are seeminly ignored. It would be nice to define what sheet is loaded. That could start with something like:
   sheet_names = xl_workbook.sheet_names()
   then use the sheet names list to enable selection of one of them and open it with something akin to:
   xl_sheet = xl_workbook.sheet_by_name(sheet_names[0])

Anyway, I hope this report is of use.

the bits of code here are taken from https://blogs.law.harvard.edu/rprasad/2014/06/16/reading-excel-with-python-xlrd/

thanks

title: CategoricalComponents are converted to numerical components on session save/store
body:
cc @JudoWill . Originally reported in #606 by @keatonb

```
>>> from glue import qglue
>>> qlue(data=dict(x=['a', 'b', 'a']))
```

Note that such a dataset is (correctly) stored as a Categorical Component

```
data._components
Out[8]: OrderedDict([(x, <glue.core.data.CategoricalComponent object at 0x108604d50>), (Pixel Axis 0, <glue.core.data.CoordinateComponent object at 0x108604d90>), (World 0, <glue.core.data.CoordinateComponent object at 0x108604e50>)])
```

However, saving+restoring the session turns X into a non-categorical component

```
Out[1]: OrderedDict([(x, <glue.core.data.Component object at 0x10f71ef50>), (Pixel Axis 0, <glue.core.data.CoordinateComponent object at 0x111fa88d0>), (World 0, <glue.core.data.CoordinateComponent object at 0x111fa8d10>)])
```

The actual information saved is

```
  "CategoricalComponent": {
    "units": null, 
    "_type": "glue.core.data.CategoricalComponent", 
    "data": {
      "_type": "numpy.ndarray", 
      "data": "k05VTVBZAQBGAHsnZGVzY3InOiAnPGY4JywgJ2ZvcnRyYW5fb3JkZXInOiBGYWxzZSwgJ3NoYXBlJzogKDMsKSwgfSAgICAgICAgICAgIAoAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAPA/AAAAAAAAAAA="
    }
  }, 
```

We should make sure that categorical components can be saved and restored to the same state

title: Segfault when loading data on Linux
body:
First reported by Markus Rexroth on the google group

```
I managed to install glue from source on Scientific Linux 6.6. However, when I open the GUI and click on the icon to load data, the program crashes with the error:

File “zmq/backend/cython/checkrc.pxd”, line 21, in zmq.backend.cython.checkrc.raise ZMQError (errno)
ZMQError: Interrupted system call

QPixmap: It is not safe to use pixmaps outside the GUI thread
QPainter::begin: Paint device returned engine == 0, type: 2
QPixmap: It is not safe to use pixmaps outside the GUI thread
QPixmap: It is not safe to use pixmaps outside the GUI thread
Segmentation fault.

When I try to test with glue –t, all tests run fine until “test_state.py” exits with a “Segmentation fault” error. Do you have an idea what the cause for the error might be?
```

We should audit the places in the code that spawn new threads (there aren't very many). New threads are basically forbidden from tinkering with GUI state, and that's one way to trigger this error message. On the other hand, it could also indicate a broken build of Qt or something else.

body:
This is triggered by the fact that 1-to-1 links reassign some ComponentIDs, meaning old plots might be using now non-existant ComponentIDs. 

You can workaround the problem by reopening plot windows after linking, but this shouldn't be necessary

title: Loading a histogram when the first data-column is non-numeric causes AttributeError
body: If the first column of the loaded dataset is non-numeric then whenever you try to generate a histogram plot the GUI throws an AttributeError (because it tries to do a histogram of NaN data).

title: glueviz doesn't recognize images with RA, Dec, Freq, Stokes as cubes
body: CASA exports cubes as RA, Dec, Freq, and Stokes, which confuses glueviz. Exporting the cube without the stokes axis (dropstokes=True in exportfits) fixes the problem, but it would be good to have a fix on glueviz's end because CASA is the default calibration software for both ALMA and the VLA.

title: glueqt fails if IPython is on PySide
body:
While trying out glue I encountered a problem you will probably want to address at some point.  I have both PyQt4 and PySide (the alternative non-GPL Qt bindings) installed on my system, and IPython (at least as of 0.13) seems to default to PySide.  glue, on the other hand, uses PyQt4. So when it tries to embed an ipython widget, it fails because ipython wants PySide objects and glue wants PyQt4. (see the error I've included below.)

The user-level fix is to invoke glue by doing `QT_API=pyqt glueqt` instead of just `glueqt`.  But you'll probably want to do this programmatically, if it's possible.

```
/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glue/qt/glue_application.pyc in _create_terminal(self=<glue.qt.glue_application.GlueApplication object>)
    313         splitter.setOrientation(Qt.Vertical)
    314         splitter.addWidget(self._ui.centralwidget)
--> 315         splitter.addWidget(widget)
        splitter.addWidget = <built-in method addWidget of QSplitter object at 0x117a6b560>
        widget = <glue.qt.widgets.terminal.EmbeddedIPythonWidget object at 0x114ff57e8>
    316         splitter.setStretchFactor(0, 5)
    317         splitter.setStretchFactor(1, 1)

TypeError: QSplitter.addWidget(QWidget): argument 1 has unexpected type 'EmbeddedIPythonWidget'
```

body: Currently, it adds the new subset to the current highlighted selection

title: Unexpected behavior for Contrast mode context menu
body: Changing the selection percentage should trigger a redraw, and enable contrast mode. It does neither currently.

title: ROI tools occasionally drawn behind data
body: With 5 subsets drawn, the lasso and circle ROI tools seem to draw behind the front data layer. The box tool is on top.

title: Clients should update component lists as they change
Scatter client doesn't reassign subsets from other data sets properly
body:
I created a scatter plot of a catalog, highlighted a subset from an image, and defined an ROI. This should reassign the subset from the image. Instead, it spawned a new subset for the catalog.

It isn't possible to use the scatter client to edit subsets in other data sets at the moment

title: Circle ROI's drawn incorrectly
body: This seems to be a problem with the newest versions of MPL, triggered when creating an Ellipse patch in device coordinates (i.e. transform=None). The workaround is to use transform=IdentityTransform()

title: Cannot save a restored session from mac build
body: The pickle fails when calling pickle.whichmodule, complaining that email.**init**.pyc doesn't have anything named bases

title: Home, back, forward, resize buttons should resample image
image subset tinted incorrectly
body:
The issue only seems to occur with matplotlib v1.1.1. Shading looks correct in v1.1.2

This appears to be a rendering issue with RGBA arrays when A != 255.

title: Live Linking should create copies of style
body:
Otherwise, changing properties after the link is broken will still update all linked styles, since they share an instance.

Requires defining a copy() method for styles, as well as an **eq** method for testing purposes

title: Histogram client: spawn mode spawns subsets for every data set
body: Should only apply to the active dataset. Does not happen with image client -- likely not an issue with the selection mode code.

title: image contrast mode failure
body: Sometimes when scaling the image contrast in min/max mode, the image is stuck at "all-white." Changing the mode to 5/95% fixes it
